DataElement.preferredName: Somatic Mutation Finding Function Change FunctionalChange
DataElement.preferredDefinition: A mutation that occurs in the somatic tissues of an organism and that will not, therefore, be heritable, since it is not present in the germ line. Somatic mutations may contribute to a disease state.:Objective evidence of disease perceptible to the examining physician (sign) and subjective evidence of disease perceived by the patient (symptom)._The normal action performed by a structure or device.:The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character._Functional change in Protein

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A mutation that occurs in the somatic tissues of an organism and that will not, therefore, be heritable, since it is not present in the germ line. Somatic mutations may contribute to a disease state.:Objective evidence of disease perceptible to the examining physician (sign) and subjective evidence of disease perceived by the patient (symptom)._The normal action performed by a structure or device.:The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A mutation that occurs in the somatic tissues of an organism and that will not, therefore, be heritable, since it is not present in the germ line. Somatic mutations may contribute to a disease state.:Objective evidence of disease perceptible to the examining physician (sign) and subjective evidence of disease perceived by the patient (symptom).

Concepts.definition: Any mutation with an origin in cells that are not destined to become gametes. As a consequence, such mutations are not transmitted to progeny, though they will be transmitted during any mitosis within the individual. Somatic mutations may contribute to a broad variety of pathologies including cancer.
Clinical, laboratory or molecular evidence, or absence of evidence of disease.

Property.preferredDefinition: The normal action performed by a structure or device.:The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.

Concepts.definition: The normal action performed by a structure or device.
The act of alteration or modification; changed or altered in form or character.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Default Conceptual Domain for UML Loader

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Functional change in Protein_Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A type of mutation in which one or more paired nucleotides are inserted or deleted in the coding region of a gene, which causes the triplet codons to be read in the wrong frame; the resulting polypeptide has a garbled amino acid sequence from the mutated codon on.

Concepts.definition: A mutation occurring within the protein-coding region of a gene which results in a shift in the reading frame of the encoded protein. Frameshift mutations often result in the premature truncation of a gene product.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Any mutation that does not cause a change in reading frame.

Concepts.definition: A mutation occurring within the protein-coding region of a gene which results in a retention of the reading frame of the encoded protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A mutation in which a base change results in substitution of one amino acid for another.  This change may result in alteration of the protein's activity or stability.

Concepts.definition: A point mutation occurring within the protein-coding region of a gene, and which codes for a different amino acid than expected.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A mutation in which a base change creates a stop codon, resulting in premature termination of a polypeptide product.

Concepts.definition: A point mutation occurring within the protein-coding region of a gene, and which codes for a stop that can truncate the protein.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A mutation that alters the DNA sequence, but encodes the same amino acid.

Concepts.definition: A point mutation occurring within the protein-coding region of a gene, and which codes for the same amino acid as expected.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A mutation that alters or abolishes the specific sequence denoting the site at which the splicing of an intron takes place. Such mutations may result in one or more introns remaining in the mature messenger RNA or fusion of non-adjacent exons and can disrupt the generation of the protein product.

Concepts.definition: Any mutation that occurs within the discrete sequences comprising the 5' or 3' splice sites of a gene that has a spliced message. Splice-site mutation may result in a deletion or insertion of extraneous amino acids in the gene product or a change in the reading frame of the spliced message.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A molecular entity formed by loose association involving two or more component molecular entities. The bonding between the components is normally weaker than in a covalent bond.: Genetic alterations found in the neoplastic lesions of the animal model. These alterations are not made intentionally.

Concepts.definition: A molecular entity formed by loose association involving two or more component molecular entities. The bonding between the components is normally weaker than in a covalent bond.
Genetic alterations found in the neoplastic lesions of the animal model. These alterations are not made intentionally.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: Type; a subdivision of a particular kind of thing.

Concepts.definition: Something distinguishable as an identifiable class based on common qualities.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: Representation term 'Type' added per request of loading team to suport SIW requirements on 7/31/2008
